I have a toxic trait of loving simulation games and in depth economy games, but the learning curve always dissuades me, as after not playing for a couple months I forget how to play it and hate the idea of having to go back through tutorials. 

There is a lot to this game and I see that as a good thing. The name is Big Ambitions and I get the feeling the devs chose that name based on their own ambitions for it. Which so far they seem to be hitting their goals with great success.

It's an early access and I've played simulation games that have been full releases, from AAA Companies with not even 10% of the care and innovation that has been put into this. *Cough* Cities: Skylines 2 *Cough*

Developers have seemed to take on a lot of community feedback for this and they in the last year expanded their team but for a small team of only like 10 people now I think I read somewhere. They are killing it. How this game isn't more well known is beyond me. 

For the game. You start off broke with an uncles guidance and a dream of being rich. How you achieve that is your choice. Do it all yourself, hire a bunch of staff, your choice. You can automate a lot of things. Design your spaces. Have car accidents. Run out of fuel. There's really just a lot to it, too much to list. Game is great to get lost in for hours on end or to just have up on the side while you're watching something on a second monitor.

My only GRIPES with the game is two things.

1. The happiness system is a bit meh in my opinion and could be more impactful on the game. E,g employees could work slower if you're on premises with them due to your mood, reducing productivity.
 
2. And this is more of my own fault and can't really be address as it is as I previously mentioned my own toxic trait. If you like to play a variety of games and find yourself coming back to it after a few months you will need to teach yourself how to play it all over again, which is quite tedious.

TL;DR - Great game, Developers are delivering what they are promising each update and listening to feedback. Great Price for how many different gameplay mechanics there is and the aesthetic is pleasing. The ambition of the developers is to deliver a FULL Entrepreneural simulation game with great economy gameplay, this is as immersive as it gets. You can tell it's a real passion for Hovgaard Games developing this.

Big Ambitions - A Deep Dive Into Strategic Growth with Room for Expansion

If you're a fan of games that emphasize strategic planning, time management, and long-term progression, Big Ambitions delivers exactly that. The game’s core strength lies in its depth—taking the time to meticulously grow your wealth over the course of 800-1000 in-game days feels rewarding. Watching your empire expand, piece by piece, is a satisfying experience, especially as you earn more money and make smarter, more strategic decisions along the way.

However, there are a few areas where Big Ambitions could really take the experience to the next level. While the overall progression system is solid, the profit margins in certain areas feel a bit tight. It would be great to see more profitability across the board, as it would give a stronger sense of achievement and make the grind even more rewarding.

Another point worth mentioning is the game’s memory handling. As you progress past the 800-1000 in-game days mark, the performance tends to struggle a bit. If the game could optimize its memory management to handle longer play sessions more smoothly, it would ensure that the pacing remains consistent throughout the entire journey.

A big wish I have for the game is more development on its features. While the current mechanics are enjoyable, there’s room to expand on them—whether through deeper customization, more in-depth businesses, or even richer NPC interactions. And speaking of expansion, an online mode could really elevate the experience, but rather than focusing on global leaderboards, a more personal, self-contained online mode could give players a chance to share their progress, interact with friends, or compete in a more low-pressure environment.

In conclusion, Big Ambitions is a game that offers an engaging and rewarding experience for those who love building from the ground up. The game’s depth and progression system are fantastic, but with a few tweaks in profit margins, memory handling, and a bit more development in online features, it could easily become a must-play for fans of management and strategy games.

This game is like the perfect game for me, it has the right amount of thinking and management but still doesn't completely overwhelm you. I would absolutely love a co-op mode, my life would be complete. The amount of customization and the ability to make something feel like your own is really nice, the city feels alive, the driving can be quirky at times but somehow still maintains a certain level of realism. The different vehicles you can buy are nice, and something about the graphics really keep me interested.

What keeps me coming back is the incredible depth and the limitless potential. I've poured countless hours into this game, built multiple successful corporations, and achieved a level of success I'm genuinely proud of, yet I’ve only unlocked 17 of the 99 achievements. That's not a sign of failure; it's a promise. It's the game telling me, "You think this is big? You've barely scratched the surface." There are still entire industries I haven't touched, strategies I haven't tried, and a whole lot more of New York to make my own.

If you have even a spark of entrepreneurial interest, if you love deep simulation games where your decisions have real weight, or if you just want to experience the ultimate rags-to-riches power fantasy, you owe it to yourself to play Big Ambitions. It’s more than a game; it's a meticulously crafted world of opportunity.

Now if you'll excuse me, I have a new retail sector to dominate. My city awaits.

[h1] Big Ambitions: The Game That Finally Gave My Degrees — and My Life — Purpose [/h1]
There was a time when I existed only in theory.
I had the papers, a Bachelor’s in Accounting, a Master’s in Business Analytics, trophies of intellect gathering digital dust. I could read balance sheets like sacred texts, forecast trends in my sleep… but for what? My days were empty cells on a spreadsheet that never balanced.

I was alive, yes, but not living.

And then... [i] Big Ambitions.[/i]

It began as a casual click, a moment of boredom disguised as curiosity. Another business simulator, I thought. But within hours, I wasn’t just playing, I was calculating, analyzing, strategizing. My dormant skills flared to life like forgotten embers suddenly fed oxygen.

For the first time, my education had a heartbeat. My accounting background wasn’t just numbers on a résumé, it was the pulse behind my empire. My analytics training wasn’t theoretical anymore, it was survival, success, strategy incarnate.

Every profit margin was a small victory. Every lease signed, every market captured — a testament to the version of me that once believed numbers could mean something. And now, they finally did.

In Big Ambitions, I wasn’t just a player. I was a CEO, a visionary, a reborn soul in a city of neon and opportunity.
The lifeless fog of my routine lifted, replaced by the electric buzz of purpose.

So here I am the accountant who found life in a ledger, the analyst who discovered meaning in a simulation.
Some play games to escape reality.
I played Big Ambitions to finally build one.

I have found another game to be addicted to. I have logged 50 hours of play in the first 4 days of having it. For an early access game it is very well polished. I don't know what else to say or compare it to so I thought I would share my experience with this game.

I started out with a humble gift shop. Eventually I opened a fresh food shop right up the road from it. Followed the tutorials some. I like how its done. Its like oh you need to open a business. It doesn't tell you what to do it lets you make the decision. I can be an impulsive person which can be great in a game like this or it can be terrible. I was sick of constantly restocking my fruit store. It ran out fast. I rented a larger location up the road and took out a 400k loan. I couldn't even barely afford the payment on the loan and was too broke to give a hoot how much more broke I got. Well I opened up this gym and got it manned 24-7 and suddenly it was printing money. I went from being broke to making 15k to 20k in a day.  I quickly paid off my loan and took out another for 800k. Lawyers make stupid money in real life so....to hell with it I will open a law firm. Rented some massive building that was pretty much next door to the bank. Struggled to get it online for a bit but once it was I was making 150k to 200k daily. This opened a lot of doors for me. I could just throw down businesses wherever I wanted to. Well the law firm is making stupid amounts of cash so I will open another. It was not making any money though. Come to find out my rival was messing with it. 

I decided I got something for you. I rented every building in Hells Kitchen that was open. Then I picked out a few of her businesses and went after them by opening my own with insanely low prices. She was making 2 million a week and now shes down to making only 1 million per week. If I was her I  would be mad that I got taken down by a guy whos only making 500k to 700k a week. Anyways success in this game feels really good. We will see where I go from here. I have almost every major property in hells kitchen. 

I whole heartedly recommend this game. I bought it on an impulse thinking the concept was cool I will probably get hundreds of hours out of this. Its an awesome gameplay loop and on top of that the music in it is pretty good.

Big Ambitions offers something special to anyone who's really into bussines management games. With free roam open world, dozens of rentable buildings you can turn into many different types of shops or other bussineses, the options are nearly endless on how you wish to build your empire. While there are a bunch of things you need to keep in mind and manage, the game itself is simple enough and explains everything well, meaning that you don't need a degree in economics to understand what the hell you're doing. And hey, watching green number go up is always satisfying.

The game also features lite life sim elements. I never found them to be too bothersome or annoying, as you really only need to eat and sleep. On the contrary, it allows you to have something you can dump money into besides more bussines. Buy a luxury car, get a penthouse and spend thousands upon thousands of dollars furnishing it, buy a yacht, just live the life of a successful bussinesman.

I'd definitely recommend this game, it's shockingly addictive, where launching the game always leads to multiple hour sessions before you realize the sun is already down and you should probably go to sleep.

So essentially, I'm in agreement with most of the reviews for this game already. Really addictive and I love the way the development of the game is going. I would like to see some quality of life improvements: camera angling, more customization options for both your character and employees, more things to do at home to increase happiness (maybe add some minigames for things your character does), more interior design options and detailed customization, maybe even dialogue/chat interactions with NPC's (not just texting or phone calls). I also notice that there are a lot of frame drops/skips - so maybe there's some improvement to be had with graphics and loading things in, asset wise in the world and map in general. (There is a lot, so it makes sense but it would be cool if the FPS can push high with a higher end pc like I have.)

There's a lot already in the game as is, but you add these details and really enhance the stability of the game and I'm sure that I will probably never stop playing this game. Just as long as I can constantly keep developing businesses and there is never nothing to do and always rivals to compete with. They become dynamic so you'll always be in some kind of self-paced competition.

The first 5-10 hours are alright, you are incredibly busy trying to keep your stores running. But once you get a proper office the game basically becomes an excel sheet and the only two reasons to ever leave your home is to drive a truck to a new factory or warehouse or to pay taxes. At some point I found myself simply sleeping 24 hours, eating then sleeping again over and over. There is a big lack of endgame challenge, just earning money for the sake of earning money

The game started out great and I was having fun building up my stores and trying to get rid of the rivals, this latest update broke the game for me.

Instead of being able to import everything you need to sell, any of the high end products you need to make. So basically no clothing, no electronics.

The factory system isn't explained or the tutorial is broken as it told me to buy things for the factory but not how many. Even in the help menu I can see what I have to purchase but it doesn't give specifics, do I need multiple? will only one do? how much product do I need to use? how many products will it produce? The how many items you need to make your product is important as you have to import those and the imports only happen once a week now. Order too few and your factory is not working for a week and you don't get products to sell.

Let me import the items and those that want to deal with manufacturing can do that.
Sort of like The Sims but also sort of like an incremental game. Getting around and taking care of needs feels like unnecessary padding. As a business sim it's milquetoast.

It's a good game but the performance is really not good. I don't have the best computer but I've played games that look a lot better than this that run way better, and even on low settings the game can sometimes dip into less than 10 frames per second, especially in interiors. I can't recommend it based on that alone. There also needs to be a few more quality of life things, it can get tedious to have to search around a wholesaler warehouse to find the product you need to buy, and the game is very unclear as to which stores stock which item.

This game isn't fun. It's actually frustrating. This game suffers from a viewing angle perspective. You can only rotate the camera left and right and zoom in and out. You cant see where you're going. You walk into a BIG warehouse to buy stuff but cant even see where the shelves are. You have to wonder around until you stumble upon what you're shopping for. Never being able to see ahead of you or where you're going is a big bummer. Why buy pictures for the walls when you cant look at the walls? If not for the viewing angle this would be a good game.

I wanted to like this game and liked the idea and mechanics, but the game camera is a nightmare. It's really difficult to see anything, and trying to rotate the camera, drive, or use the map was nauseating. I tried to power through after I started developing a headache, thinking it would get better as I got used to the camera, but in the end it was unplayable for me. I can't recommend this to anyone with even a touch of motion sickness.
Game has gotten significantly worse and needs a patch fix as of 10/18/2025. Often crashes trying to load and lags way more than normal.

I’ve played other games by this publisher and enjoyed them, and I’m a big fan of simulation/management games in general. However, this one takes the realism a bit too far for my taste. It plays almost like a real-life simulator — you wake up, go to work, deal with traffic, buy groceries nearly every day, eat, then sleep and repeat. If you even lightly bump your car, you’ll spend the rest of the day arranging recovery and repairs before you can drive again, which can feel frustrating.

For players who want something that mirrors real life as closely as possible, this will probably be a great fit. The commerce side of the game is well done, and I can see why some people love it. Personally, though, I found the day-to-day cycle quite slow and it ended up feeling more like a chore than a game.
I was a fan in the beginning. Now this game is too complicated to have fun.

But once you get a proper office the game basically becomes an excel sheet and the only two reasons to ever leave your home is to drive a truck to a new factory or warehouse or to pay taxes. At some point I found myself simply sleeping 24 hours, eating then sleeping again over and over. There is a big lack of endgame challenge, just earning money for the sake of earning money

The game started out great and I was having fun building up my stores and trying to get rid of the rivals, this latest update broke the game for me.

Instead of being able to import everything you need to sell, any of the high end products you need to make. So basically no clothing, no electronics.

The factory system isn't explained or the tutorial is broken as it told me to buy things for the factory but not how many. Even in the help menu I can see what I have to purchase but it doesn't give specifics, do I need multiple? will only one do? how much product do I need to use? how many products will it produce? The how many items you need to make your product is important as you have to import those and the imports only happen once a week now. Order too few and your factory is not working for a week and you don't get products to sell.

Let me import the items and those that want to deal with manufacturing can do that.
Sort of like The Sims but also sort of like an incremental game. Getting around and taking care of needs feels like unnecessary padding. As a business sim it's milquetoast.

It's a good game but the performance is really not good. I don't have the best computer but I've played games that look a lot better than this that run way better, and even on low settings the game can sometimes dip into less than 10 frames per second, especially in interiors. I can't recommend it based on that alone. There also needs to be a few more quality of life things, it can get tedious to have to search around a wholesaler warehouse to find the product you need to buy, and the game is very unclear as to which stores stock which item.

This game isn't fun. It's actually frustrating. This game suffers from a viewing angle perspective. You can only rotate the camera left and right and zoom in and out. You cant see where you're going. You walk into a BIG warehouse to buy stuff but cant even see where the shelves are. You have to wonder around until you stumble upon what you're shopping for. Never being able to see ahead of you or where you're going is a big bummer. Why buy pictures for the walls when you cant look at the walls? If not for the viewing angle this would be a good game.

I wanted to like this game and liked the idea and mechanics, but the game camera is a nightmare. I can't recommend this to anyone with even a touch of motion sickness.

I’ve played other games by this publisher and enjoyed them, and I’m a big fan of simulation/management games in general. However, this one takes the realism a bit too far for my taste. It plays almost like a real-life simulator — you wake up, go to work, deal with traffic, buy groceries nearly every day, eat, then sleep and repeat. If you even lightly bump your car, you’ll spend the rest of the day arranging recovery and repairs before you can drive again, which can feel frustrating.

For players who want something that mirrors real life as closely as possible, this will probably be a great fit. The commerce side of the game is well done, and I can see why some people love it. Personally, though, I found the day-to-day cycle quite slow and it ended up feeling more like a chore than a game.
I was a fan in the beginning. Now this game is too complicated to have fun.
